February 24, 1955.

Dear Mr. Buckland,

I am writing to you in response to your letter dated [date]. I have received your questionnaire and would like to express my gratitude for your prompt attention to it.

We have reviewed your questionnaire and found it to be quite comprehensive. We appreciate your thoroughness and the effort you have put into it.

If you require any further assistance or information, please do not hesitate to contact us. We are always here to help.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
[Your Position]
[Your Company]

P.S. Thank you very much for making this material available to me.
February 24, 1955.

Mr. William J. Buckland,
R.R. 4, Box 931 - C,
Tampa, Florida.
U.S.A.

Dear Mr. Buckland:

We have received questionnaire no. 2 which you completed and returned to us as well as the four photographs which you enclosed.

I notice that you would like copies of two of the pictures if possible. Although we do make copies in special circumstances where the picture is being used for a particular occasion, we find that we are unable to do so to a very great extent. If it is agreeable with you therefore we will keep the pictures as you stated in your letter, and if we find it necessary to have copies made for any purpose we will see that copies are sent to you. The one showing the holding of water for Davidson is particularly interesting and representing the solution of one of the very pressing problems of modern life.

Thank you very much for making this material available to us.

Yours sincerely,

Evelyn Bager
Assistant Archivist

Dear Sir,

I am now finishing the questionnaire you sent us.

In regard to question (a) 3 I am sending a few pictures, the one of my farm, the one of R. D. Idaho farm, and the one of Mrs. Sande & Co. Wishing the jubilee every success.

Sincerely,

R. E. Buckland

PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering these questionnaires.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires

- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Ruby E. M. Rosborough Nov. 27, 1907. Davidson, Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? No.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

One Brother came out to visit but went home again.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Very hard times. My goods were frozen & dried out 5' ames. Hauled out once. Drew gravel 6 miles to Davidson. 1/2 yds to a load for $2.50 for building furnaces. Draw hay to Silver Barns for $2.00 a load.

The last few years I lived there, I drew water in a barrel to Davidson for drinking water at 5 cents a half or 75 cents a barrel. The water was from a spring on my homestead on the Arrow River Bible.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

Among our neighbors. In summer time we went with horse & buggy. In winter time a horse made sleigh.

In spring of 1915 we sold out and went back home to Ontario.

Uncle Brother came but to visit but went home again.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Very hard times. My crops were frozen & dried out 5 times. Hauled out once. Drew gravel 6 miles to Davidson. 1/2 yd to a load for $2.50 for building hayloft. Drew hay to Sillery Barns for a road.

The last few years I lived there, I drew water in a barrel to Davidson for drinking water at 5 cents a barrel or 75 cents a barrel. The water was from a spring on my homestead on the Arrow River side.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

Among our neighbors. In summer time we went with horse & buggy. In winter time a horse made sleigh.

In spring of 1915 we sold out and went back home to Ontario.
25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1910 or 1912.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What maker?

We couldn't afford one.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? 6½ miles to Moondam Bank.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

We did continue to trade in Moondam.

To new towns and some had a car.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? About once a week, or if we needed something we would go.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

People went to town any time things were needed so all were farmers so couldn't always go on Saturdays.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogs? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Sent for bedding & clothes in 1905 or 1906. There were no Department stores in Moondam. Then after I was married in 1907, we sent for dried fruits (as we knew of Prunes, Raisins & Apricots) and Soap by the Box. Also a lot of Clothes & other things. Soap for children.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

We didn't have a telephone. It was the Bell Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out?

I intended to stay permanently.
